instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3476: What is 820-3476? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A  No Power on...
threads.message:
Green light turns on and then turns to orange. Even with no battery plugged in. The customer states no liquid dmg but smelled something burning. I looked for any signs of damage thoroughly under the scope Looks brand new. I checked the 2 power rails this is what i have so far.
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> is present
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> i get 16 volts till it gets to the <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> chip after f7140 and before i get .0754 ? is this normal or is voltage here only present when lcd is plugged in ?? is <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> messed up ?

This is my first real customer board...

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A  No Power on...
threads.message: When i put multi meter on diode mode and probes on f7140 there seems to be a short to ground... reading starts at .089 then drosp to zero.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A  No Power on...
threads.message: When i put the power to it wont let me go past 2.4v and stuck at 5 amps

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A  No Power on...
threads.message: Well, F7140 is dead for sure and 16V on PPBUS is what killed it. Also putting 5A into the board something must heat up, find that first because I suspect it may be the CPU

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A  No Power on...
threads.message: Duke the caps next to the CPU are blown to shit!! How do you know these things its a miracle!

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A  No Power on...
threads.message: They were covered by a tape...

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A  No Power on...
threads.message: Sort out the issue on PPBUS first, it should never be higher than 12.6V!

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A  No Power on...
threads.message: I need a donor board for this macbook and cant find one... where should i look ?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A  No Power on...
threads.message: Duke after i removed the bad caps im getting 12.56 on f7140 like you said...

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A  No Power on...
[SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A  No Power on...
threads.message: ok, replace cap and it should work I think.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A  No Power on...
threads.message:
No Title

Add another to the List thanks DUKE!!!
